Reviews.Content: I first stayed at The Central Park Hotel in 1987, returned in 1990 and recently stayed again (Nov. 2005). I must say that the Hotel has gone down a bit in my opinion. The one good thing about the Central Park Hotel is that it is clean and has a convenient location (although the Queensway tube station is closed until May 2006, you have to use either the Bayswater or Lancaster Gate stations - a bit of a hike). The water pressure in the shower is terrible in the morning and not much better late at night. I learned to take a shower at 5:00 pm to get the full water pressure. Also it is on a street of inexpensive hotels so it can be noisy even if you stay on a top floor. Check-in time is not until 3:00 pm (1500 hours) which is terrible if you just arrived from a long flight and are exhausted. You can leave your luggage with the concierge, however they are not shy in expecting a tip. The whole Bayswater/Padddington neighborhood frankly has a Middle Eastern feel to it which did not thrill me. On the plus side the Hotel is clean, breakfast is decent, and you are right next to wonderful Kensington Gardens. The staff was quite pleasant and friendly as well. They have also have added safe deposit boxes in each room which are easy to utilize. All in all I would recommend this place because for the price it is a good bargain.

Reviews.Title: “Beware of Bait & Switch at the Central Park”
Reviews.Author: kaddee
Reviews.Content: Our party of travelers booked this hotel in early Oct due to a fantastic special offer rate of only 60 USD per night. Because the rate seemed so low, even for the off-peak season, I sent an email to the Central Park requesting a confirmation at the 60 US Dollars per-night price for our stay from 23-27 Nov 2005. The General Manager sent me a reply affirming that not only was the 60 USD nightly rate correct, but it was (Quote) "guaranteed". We arrived as planned on the night of 23 Nov, only to be told while checking in that the rate was 60 pounds, vs. dollars. I had a copy of the email reply I received from the Central Park general manager and showed it to the desk agent. The agent said that although the email did clearly state the 60 USD rate as being correct, that the price was actually not valid, and that we couldn't check in until we allowed the extra charges in pounds to be assessed on our bill. I asked where the manager was and was told that the managers worked between 9-5pm and were gone for the day. We had cell phones that worked in the United Kingdom with us, and requested that a manager call us the next day. But we were told that management just doesn't do that, we must see them in person. We had pre-booked full day sightseeing tours over the next 2 days, hence we were not going to be able to speak with a manager during their working hours. I find it unsatisfactory that anyone with the authority to make decisions at a central London hotel is only available to discuss issues with guests from 9-5pm...typically a time frame that most guests would be out sightseeing. The desk agent also told me that there was no one with managerial authority available on the night shift to discuss the matter with. We felt forced to sign the check-in form, as it would be difficult, if not impossible to find other lodging at the time. But I emphatically stated that I'd proceed to dispute this matter via my credit card company for resolution. I felt this wouldn't pose a problem on my end as I had the email from the hotel manager to submit as proof. The next morning, as we were waiting to depart for a sightseeing tour in the lobby, I was told that a manager was in the building early and would see me. Though not the same manager as had signed the email, this individual read that confirmation email I'd received from his counterpart and told us that certainly there was no problem, we'd only be charged the 60 USD per-night rate, it was the hotel policy to honor that confirmed price. We carried on, glad the problem was behind us- or so we thought. In the morning on the day before our departure, we were called to the desk while in the lobby, and were told by the desk agent that there seemed to be a problem with our room charge. I explained what had transpired with the manager we spoke to a couple of days earlier, and that all had been resolved. The agent said no, that there was a note left to charge us 60 pounds vs. 60 dollars, and if we didn't pay that amount immediately, we'd be locked out of our rooms. I asked to see a manager, as it was after their 9am shift arrival. Another, different manager was summoned and I explained the situation, once again providing the email I received from the Central Park General Manager guaranteeing the special 60 US dollar rate. He took our paperwork in the back and didn't say a word. We waited and waited. I told the desk clerk once again that if we didn't get the guaranteed rate that I'd gladly dispute it through my credit card company- a dispute that I was certain to win based on the clearly worded email I'd received from the hotel. The desk clerk went back to see the manager and check status on what he was doing, as it was taking considerable time. Finally the desk agent (not the manager) returned and stated that we could have the rooms at the 60 dollar per night rate, but they'd only accept cash in US dollars. We strongly felt that the only reason Central Park caved was due to my decision to dispute it via the credit card issuer- a case they didn't stand a chance of winning, as we had written proof. And although it seemed like outright extortion on the part of the hotel, we paid them the US dollar cash amount straightaway and requested a receipt. The time spent waiting for final resolution that morning alone took 2 hours from start to finish. All told, we spent a considerable part of our trip going back and forth with the Central Park staff over this issue, losing valuable touring time in London. Only in the end (our last full day in town) to be reluctantly told that we'd be charged the initially quoted rate of 60 USD. I feel a class establishment would have gone the extra mile and even offered us some sort of compensation for our troubles & lost time, which were all their fault (perhaps a breakfast upgrade, etc.)...but it's clear that the Central Park just doesn't have such consideration in them. As an individual who has traveled extensively since my youth, I found this situation utterly appalling. The fact that the Central Park wasn't willing to honor their own email specifically 'guaranteeing' our room rates, that it took so much back and forth time wasted on the part of their guests to resolve, and that management - when available- seemed totally incompetent. We couldn't believe that they freely dumped the bulk of this problem on the front line desk staff to act as 'go-betweens' and do all of the dirty work of this touchy issue vs. showing some real leadership and taking control of the issue and resolution themselves. It is worth noting that we witnessed other disgruntled guests complaining at the front desk, they also were obviously frustrated with the lack of management intervention with their concerns. Why even have managers if they're not capable of handling sensitive customer concerns and complaints? And why so many managers who seem to do so little besides collect a pay check? My recommendation to the owners of the Central Park is rid your establishment of your inferior managers, or at least cut some of the fat from that layer as they are ineffective. Hire some qualified management, well-versed in customer service and proper principles of hospitality, as your current crop is not. Accept that once in awhile, a reputable business will realize they have to 'bite the bullet' or eat the cost every now and again or offer some sort of compensation in the interest of their customers. Especially when the error is not on the part of your client, but on yours. That's what true quality of service is. I think you could save yourself some of that ill-spent managerial salary money by hiring real professionals in their place vs. those slackers now on your payroll. Also consider giving your front line desk staff a big raise- they were the absolute picture of grace under fire while doing what should have been their fat cat bosses' jobs. These employees maintained a sense of class and calm throughout the ordeal thrust upon them. To anyone planning to stay at the Central Park, you may want to reconsider- as we all know, they're not the only game in town. London abounds with hotels, I urge you to consider other accomodations in Bayswater or elsewhere in town. Please beware: Even if you have a written special rate 'guarantee' sent from the hotel itself, our experience is that it is NOT necessarily going to be the rate you'll be charged once there. If you do decide to risk booking, even after reading this, then I advise you to pay by a credit card issuer with a dependable dispute process for questionable charges. Sad to say, you just might have to resort to going that route with this hotel!

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed London stay at Central Park”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Central Park Hotel in October for one week and were more than satisfied. I'd booked on Expedia after finding a very reasonable rate for central London, about $120 Cdn/night. I was a bit worried after reading a few negative reviews but my fears were promptly allayed at check-in. We found the room to be very clean if not terribly spacious. It certainly contained all the necessities: nice large, firm bed, clean bathroom with excellent water pressure and even a tiny fridge. As said, the room was a bit tiny but certainly nothing worse than often encountered in large cities. The hotel staff was helpful. The young woman who greeted us was more than happy to give us our room well before the 2:00pm check-in time. Requests for extra towels or a glass of ice were happily filled. The complimentary continental breakfast is OK if you just want a bit of toast and coffee in the am. The cooked breakfast is a bit dismal, if you feel like trying a full english I'd suggest going outside the hotel. In all, we were very happy with the Central Park hotel and would not hesitate to stay there again. Note:(see pic) you have to put your key card into a little outlet next to the main light switch to turn on the lights/TV-clever powersavers too!

Reviews.Title: “Tolerable, for the most part”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I was willing to tolerate a hotel of this caliber, only because of the price and its location within the city of London. The room itself was clean enough, but not luxurious by any standard. The bathroom, which is an important feature to me, was clean and modern. The beds were comfortable enough. The main problem with this hotel was the noise. We took the advice of a previous reviewer and requested a room toward the back. For the most part, outside noise was not a problem. However, there was a considerable amount of noise from within the hotel. We felt compelled to whisper in our own room after 10:00 pm for fear of disturbing others. One night, there was a very loud domestic disturbance in the room next to ours, which went on until midnight. We finally called the desk to complain and we heard the hotel staff speaking to the combatants within five minutes. Other noise continued, however, and we heard every door slam, every conversation, laughter, vacuuming, etc. The desk staff was polite, with the exception of the concierge, who didn't seem to understand the nature of his job. When we inquired about the weather forecast one day, and he told us to check the newspaper. On a positive note, we were offered an upgrade to a corner room one night, an "executive double" for the same price. It was much more spacious and a little bit quieter. The breakfast was horrible. Bread, strange looking granola, cornflakes, and shot-glasses of room temperature water and OJ. To sum it up, this hotel was tolerable, but only because of the price. We paid about $100/night.

Reviews.Title: “A great deal, but”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: After visiting this site, we booked a room for three nights. Basically, we'd stay there again for a short visit. It's clean, with a great location, the staff was very polite, for only 48 GBP a night! Having said that, our other experience was: They absolutely refused to tell us if we were getting a renovated room or not. I asked via email three times, and they finally said they didn't book the specific room until guests arrived. Luckily, all rooms had been renovated by the time we got there. The other issue is the noise. There is no air conditioning, so we had to keep the windows open for air. It's VERY noisy in the street below, with people hanging out talking. I missed the tip that we should ask for a room in the back, that apparently solves the problem. But if they wouldn't tell me what room I'd be in last time, I'm not sure they'd do it next time. So if you're going in cold weather, you're all set. I don't care about breakfast, I only did the continental after reading the reviews, there is a lovely French bakery a couple of blocks away on Queensway. And the hotel continental breakfast is all you can eat, so if you want more juice or anything, you just have to take it. The bathroom is ridiculously small, but again, for a quick visit with great tube access, it's fine. And it was clean. So for such a great rate, I was happy.

Reviews.Title: “Good base, but be careful”
Reviews.Author: GarryOttawa
Reviews.Content: Stayed here a few nights in Sept. 2005. Good location and neighbourhood, not too touristy. Easy to get everywhere. The room was clean, recently renovated, and reasonably clean (could use some work). There was no a/c, and though it was cool enough outside, with the windows open, there was a lot of road noise,and people screaming at all hours of the night. The beds were not very comforatable. The fridge did not work. The front desk staff and concierge were mostly unhelpful. There are rooms in the basement, so make sure when you reserve you don't get put there. The breakfast is a joke; its basically stale bread and old rolls. If you want the real breakfast you have to pay 7pounds extra per person.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel, good location”
Reviews.Author: NuNation
Reviews.Content: Stayed in the hotel from September 26 to September 29 2005. My wife and I in one double room, and my parents in another double room. The rooms were both clean, they seemed relatively new, and they supplied us with everything we need for a stay in London (considering of course, that you will be spending most of the time sightseeing, shopping etc.). Private bathrooms with shower/bathtub, refrigerator, safe, and tv (although the channels provided were not much, among other two arabic speaking channels). The rooms were not big, but more than big enough for a few days stay. The free continental breakfast was not much, but also that more than good enough. For me personally the most important is to fill up my stomache a little before going out, doing all the tourist-things. Lunch and dinner we ate other places. I don't know, maybe I'm less picky than other people, but I don't understand people who complain about the size of the rooms (when it's enough place to put our 3 suitcases and hang our clothes), and people who complains about the breakfast (it's free! In most hotels you have to pay for the breakfast, and you probably don't get so much better breakfast anyway. By the way, you could also get some more breakfast (English breakfast) for 4 pounds. We didn't take advantage of that, since we were satisfied with the continental breakfast provided.) Another thing very good about the hotel is the location. It's in a quiet neighbourhood in Bayswater. Just across the Bayswater road, you can find Hyde park/Kensington Gardens. It's also close to the underground. It took us about 5 minutes to walk to Bayswater station with the circle line and district lines (off course with easy connections to other lines), and it took us about 10 minutes to walk to Lancaster gate (central line). Lancaster gate is not the closest stop on the central line, the Queensway station is only 2 minutes walk from the hotel, but that station is closed until May 2006. So if you travel after May 2006, the review gets even better, then you can forget about Lancaster Gate, and you have the central line just 2 minutes from the hotel. This line just has a few stops before you're in Oxford street, and just a few stops before connections to places like trafalgar square, theatre district, and so on. The central line also is the easiest line to use if you arrive to London Stanstead airport, because the train/coaches there goes to Liverpool Street Station or Stratford (like we did), and the central line has stops in both those places. But of course, the best thing about the hotel is the price. We booked the hotel from the hotels own website, and paid £65 per night per room incl all taxes, and when we got a clean room, free breakfast and very easy location to the underground, this hotel has to get a good review. We don't have so much to say about the staff, since we basically only saw them during check-in and check-out. The hotel kept our baggage for free after checking-out, the few hours that were left before we had to go to the airport, and we could do some last-minute sightseeing/shopping. I would definetely recommend it, and if I get the same nice prices I will definetely stay there again the next time I go to London.

Reviews.Title: “Great location and great value”
Reviews.Author: carol55
Reviews.Content: Have just returned from a 2-day stay at the Central Park Hotel. We were two adults each travelling with two children, and had two triple rooms located on the third floor. GOOD: The location is excellent. Just off Bayswater, about 100 yards from Hyde Park/Kensington Gardens. Bayswater underground station is about 5 mins walk away and it took me 15 mins to walk from Paddington railway station. We mainly used London Bus for transport. You can buy one-day bus passes in a small shop next to the bus stop just around the corner from the hotel. The main buses which pass along Baywater take you into Oxford Street or down to Westminster Bridge. Ideal for sightseeing. The rooms were clean and well maintained. We had a mini-fridge, small TV mounted on the wall, hairdrier and three single beds. There was also a safe for valuables and tea/coffee making facilities. Check-in was very quick and easy and I found the staff helpful and polite. In terms of cost - each triple room cost us £81 a night. Very good value for London. NOT-SO-GOOD The rooms were very small. We had no storage space for clothes except for a few hangers in a wardrobe area. There were no drawers at all - not even in the bedside locker. This may have been because our triple room may be the same size as a standard double (?). Triple rooms are compact to say the least. We only stayed two nights and had very little luggage, but if we were there for a week I think we would have been tripping over our suitcases which had to remain on the floor. (I have read in another review that the size of rooms in Central Park can vary, so it may be worth enquiring in advance. I certainly will if we return and need another triple room). The bathroom has also tiny. There was a good size bath with shower head above it, WC and wash-hand basin. But the door opens into the only standing space in the bathroom. However, the bathroom was very clean and towels good and there was plenty of very hot water. Our rooms were at the front of the hotel. We had plenty of light but it was noisy. There is no AC so you need to keep the window open for ventilation. We all found the city/traffic noise very distracting the first night, but then we all live in quiet areas at home and are not used to city noise. The rooms at the back of the hotel are darker but probably quieter. I agree with other reviewers about the poor quality of breakfast. The glasses for orange juice are TINY. We ended up taking 2 glasses at a time and constantly refilling them - but it annoying. The orange juice is also watery and inconsistent. The tea and coffee was just adequate. The continental breakfast consists of toast, rolls or croissants with jam and butter. The croissants were OK and we tended to stick to these. The area where breakfast is served is in the basement with no windows. The tables are very canteen-like and the room has an unpleasant gloomy atmosphere. But you are not there long enough for it to really bother you. Small point but one worth noting. We had problems getting the safe in our room to work. The instructions on the safe tell you to enter 3 digits and then press 'B'. Actually you need to press 'A' not 'B'. Pressing 'B' meant we could not re-open the safe without getting the Duty Manager to use a special key. Save effort and time and instead enter 3 digits and then press 'A'. They will change the instruction labels eventually! HOWEVER, I would definitely say the positives outweigh the negatives - at least for a short stay - and would recommend this hotel to people wanting a good value, no-frills hotel in a great location. Hope this information has been useful.

Reviews.Title: “Good location”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Small renovated room on the 2nd fl.The room was ok but we had no a-c.The breckfast wasn't great unless you paid.The staff seemed friendly enough.Bathroom was small but ok.Seemed over-priced to us.Location is good.

Reviews.Title: “Not a bad hotel, but there is a variation in Standard of Rooms”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Have read the previous reviews of this hotel, and took the advice and asked for a room on either the 1st/2nd/3rd floor - which apparently are the rooms which have been renovated. First night had a double on the 2nd floor - Room 221 which was directly opposite the lift, which you could hear "pinging" as it arrived at the floor - didn't bother me, but if your sensitive to noise it might do. View was of some building being renovated behind. The room was reasonable size though not huge, bathroom was compact but useable with a bath with overhead shower. Room was clean, huge bed, and room also had a fridge, but didn't like the small tv which was up very high on a stand. From the second night onward I had a room on the first floor, which seemed more renovated than the one on the 2nd floor, and quite a bit more spacious, the bathroom had lots of free space with room to walk around even - which is very unusual for a hotel at this price in London. Again the view from the window was nothing much, just the back of some other building I think. - While the room was very clean and I couldn't complain, the windows on both the 1st and 2nd floors could do with a wash from the outside... lots of bird poo etc... and this lack of window cleaning is probably due to the outside not being very accessible. Haven't tried the breakfast - I tended to spend my late nights out and mornings in bed, so can't comment. Location good, short walk to Lancaster Gate tube (or Queensway when it opens again). Concierge particularly helpful, and staff generally friendly. For the price I got £65 average per night for a double room, with this central location I wouldn't fault the hotel. In my view it represents good value for money and you can't beat the location. I would stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Only if Desperate”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The hotel was safe, convenient and relatively inexpensive (less than $150 a night) BUT the staff are horrible/unhelpful, the street is lined with other inexpensive hotels filled with drunk college students who hang out of their windows at all hours of the night making noise. I would rate a Motel 6 in the states higher than this.

Reviews.Title: “A Hotel That Cuts Corners”
Reviews.Author: Aussie_Charlotte
Reviews.Content: We stayed in this hotel in May 2005 for 7 days. On the first night I noticed grey hairs in the middle of the carpet. We do not have grey hair - obviously the carpet hadn't been vaccuumed. Those grey hairs remained there for our whole stay - no-one vacuumed our carpet for the 7 days. Nor did they change our sheets once. The same was said for our bathroom floor. Be careful when opening the curtains as the attachments holding the curtain rods are only held up by a single screw each side. The curtains and rod came crashing down on my head the first time I opened them! The free breakfast is cheap and nasty - stale bread, cereal and watered down orange juice. Don't pay the 4 pounds for the hot breakfast which also uses the cheapest ingredients - there are better breakfasts for the same price along the Queensway. Our double room had a view of a wall. It wasn't a bad size but the walls were very thin - we could hear every word of our neighbours'. I am not recommending this hotel to anyone.

Reviews.Title: “Overall a pleasant stay”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the hotel for four nights. Rooms were small but clean and comfortable. Fridge in room a plus. Enjoyed the continental breakfast every morning and you could upgrade to full breakfast if you wanted to. We loved the area - all types of shops and restaurants close by, an easy walk. Bus stop at end of street. Bayswater tube station is about a five minute walk (Queensway is presently closed). We found the front street quite busy and noisy especially if we had the window open, i.e. people passing by, scooters, cars, delivery trucks - it never seemed to stop. Lobby had a lounge area which was nice at the end of the day to stop and have a drink and/or snack.

Reviews.Title: “Comfortable beds at last”
Reviews.Author: NessieC
Reviews.Content: We have just returned from a tour around England and the Central Park was a surprisingly good value find. Yes - the continental breakfast is a bit boring (as other reviews have suggested) but it is included in the price where other London hotels do not provide it at all. Our twin room was not spacious but it had comfortable beds, new furnishings and was very clean. Having a small fridge in the room was a bonus. The bathroom was tiny and lacked any towel rails or hooks but the shower had good pressure and hot water. The extras such as a shower cap, toiletries were a pleasant surprise. It is a relatively noisy location as are most hotels in London, but was handy to tube stations on 2 different lines (although Queensway on the central line is now closed for renovations until 2006). Compared to other London hotels we have stayed at this one is a good value gem. The pictures on the hotel's own website are a good match up to what you will find. We would definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “just don't do it”
Reviews.Author: lisainbelfast
Reviews.Content: This is one of the worst places I have ever stayed. The staff were unfriendly, they had misplaced our reservation and weren't into much of a hurry to find it, even though it was pre-paid. The decor was old and tatty throughout, the bedroom had a radiator that looked positively dangerous as it was hanging off the wall, and made loud clunky noise all the way through the night keeping us awake. There was barely room to turn around in the room. Breakfast was a poor buffet and you had to pay extra for cooked food. All in all I’d say you'd be better off with a cardboard box under Waterloo Bridge. Thanks goodness we only had to stay one night.

Reviews.Title: “An excellent value and great location”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We found the Central Park Hotel a very comfortable, quiet and clean and affordable hotel in a wonderful neighborhood that is a great location. We read all the reviews before going and took advantage in making our reservation at the hotel website which offers on-line reservations that are less expensive than several booking sites, and we were able to ask on the website order form for a newly refurbished non-smoking room on one of the lower floors. Our rate was below 50 pounds, but it was winter. We got exactly what we asked for. The room was no-smoking room (perhaps all of the rooms are no-smoking.) It was well heated, a good thing because we had furious weather outside dipping down below freezing for two of the days. Our room was in the front with a window looking out on the street. Since we only slept in the room, the plain furnishings were all we needed. There was a small fridge in the room, a convenience. The bathroom was tight quarters but adequate and clean. The room was cleaned every day. There was a desk and one chair. The television was suspended from high on the wall facing the twin beds. The room was narrow, only wide enough for the two beds with about two feet between, but it was about 15 feet long. The breakfast buffet in the basement dining room was fine. There was a choice between the complimentary croissants, butter and jam, with unlimited orange juice, coffee or tea or a hot breakfast. Getting repeat cups of coffee or decaf was a huge plus for a heavy coffee drinker, who usually has to pay for each cup. The hot buffet was quite adequate, if not offering a lot of choices. You could purchase the breakfast for 4 pounds or take the complimentary continental breakfast, and take both if you wanted. The hot foods included stewed tomatoes (of course), fried eggs and plenty of bacon, cheese. We ate there every day of a four day stay and did not get bored (though at home we would have chosen to fix a variety of things.) The large breakfast room had room for 15 tables, with another room for overflow beyond. There were no windows in the breakfast room, but it was a pleasant place to eat, and the food was a bargain. The staff was friendly and helpful. A simple bar in the large lounge was okay. The elevators worked well. The location was excellent, just a couple of hundred feet from Kensington Gardens and a block and a half from the nearest metro station. We were able to walk to Kensington Palace from there, and there is a wonderful playground for children dedicated to Princess Di only a few hundred feet from the hotel. There are several good restaurants in the neighborhood but we actually ate away in Picadilly Circus since we went to theatre a lot. It was easy to get to and from everything in London from there. Buying a discount pass for the metro made it easy and inexpensive to get around the city fast. There were people from many countries staying at the hotel, young and old. It's not a classy hotel, though the lobby looks that way--but it is fine for people who don't want to live in their room. We'll come back on our next trip, and we recommend the Central Park Hotel highly.

Reviews.Title: “Liked it, room was big for London”
Reviews.Author: MandyZS
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I stayed here for two nights two seperate times in a week. Both our rooms faced a dirty building a few feet away with scaffolding. That was the worst part. The room was large for London standards for the price which was around $120 a night, even if the bathroom was a little small, though not tiny. The continental breakfast was enough (after seconds), but it was mostly toast and two choices of cereal. Other than breakfast and the view from the window, I was fairly satisfied with this hotel, and would probably go back.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: GusGeorgia
Reviews.Content: My husband and I recently stayed at the Central Park Hotel In London. WOW What a great hotel!!! We were really surprised at how great this hotel was!!! It is right across the street from Kensington Gardens and the Tube was two streets away with two different stations!!! The Lobby was very nice- similiar to any hotel you might find in the US. The staff was very helpful and nice!! Our room was small and didn't have much storage space, but we really liked it!! It had twin beds and a full shower/tub and toilet. It was always very clean. We had a Tv and a tea pot to make tea or coffee. It overlooked Queensborough Road which is a cute road and had many other hotels down the street. We felt very comfortable here and the breakfast each morning was okay- cereal, crossiants, rolls and a tiny tiny glass of orange juice- it usually sustained us for most the day - so it was just enough. The location was great we enjoyed being so close to Kensington Gardens and Palace and spent many days wondering through the park. I would stay at this hotel again when I am in London- I would recommend this hotel for anyone!!!

Reviews.Title: “Average”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 10days Feb, 2005 This is your average hotel, it is grand in no way, I think a more accurate rating would be 2stars....but for the price, we did not complain. We were out and about so much that it didn't matter anyway, furthermore, they provided clean sheets and shower so... Pros: Excellent location, easy access to everything from the tube to local buses that can take you anywhere...we walked everywhere. Our room was huge by European hotel room standards, maids were prompt in cleaning everyday, friendly staff. Hyde Park/Kensington Gardens across the street. Though check-out was at 12 we had an hour extension (no extra $) and since we had so much time to kill before our flight...we checked out, left our luggage with the concierge for 4 hours until we were headed to Heathrow. Cons: Lobby area/carpet could use a face lift, it reaked of smoke and was quite outdated. We had to change rooms b/c construction was being done (we were first on floor 1 then moved to floor 4). We choose to eat the so-so croissants every morning...jelly, oj, coffee, tea....After a few days we started looking into the paid breakfast but trust me, it does not even look appetizing.... we saw 1 couple over the course of our ten days ever purchase it. We would buy food at the grocery nearby and eat that as an option.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Place... Great Bar... Cool For Families”
Reviews.Author: womey
Reviews.Content: I got to stay at the Central Park out of sheer desperation back in 1998. I did so because the (3) other hotels I'd attempted to book were not at all what I had come to expect from an American hotel. I've since realized that the smaller accomodations in London are part of its charm and that a British 4-star is just culturally different from an American 4-star. The Central Park has a european flair but if you're looking for any sign of back home accomodations, the Central Park has it. The hotel is near the Bayswater area and so is conveniently located to many tube stops including Queensway, Lancaster Gate, and the important Paddington station. I was able to book a good rate right off of the street, with my bags in hand and had a great breakfast each day I was there. Enjoy !

Reviews.Title: “loved it!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I just got back from a trip to london where I stayed at the Central Park Hotel In Bayswater, before my trip i read comments on this website which made me slightly nervous upon arrival, expecting the worst but after a slight confusion about booking and paying which was my fault really but the receptionist was kind and patient with the situation and when we got into the room I was pleasently surprised. I knew to ask for a room on the first three floors from comments on here, which I did as they had been newly refurbished, so the room was at quite a high standard in my opinion, okay the room was tiny but enough for me and my friends and the tv did only have 2 channels that were foreign but did play english music and the water was luke warm but bearable but for the time we were in the hotel it was perfect for us and being only 1 minute from hyde park which is great this time of year and within 2 minutes of lots of great shops and lots of fast food places and restaurants, too many to choose from! and also having a mall with big shops and a cinema was perfect we ended up going both nights of our stay. Two tubes are within 2 minutes walking distance and take u right into the centre which is ideal!the room comes with a free continental breakfast, the continent was a small selection between england and france but was just right offering cereal, toast, crossiants, bread rolls and nice orange juice which is all you really need in early morning. I didnt find the walls thin and bearly heard any noise outside, i slept very well on a comfortable bed and felt comfortable leaving valuables in the room as there was a free safe available where u choose ur own pin. The rooms were well cleaned and I found the staff friendly and helpful and the location was so perfect I wouldn't hesitiate to stay again!

Reviews.Title: “Very Nice”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The Central Park Hotel was a very nice stay, the rooms were clean and tidy and the beds were very comfortable, there was a bit of work being done outside but in my estimation for the price and location this hotel is a bargain!!!!

Reviews.Title: “clean and convenient”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Me and my wife stayed for four nights at the 4th floor from November 18. Great location, very near to a tube station, the room was small but brand new ,with clean good working bathroom. We got more than what we paid for. Though we could clearly hear the hot next door couples doing it, but we did not mind on the contrary it was quite arousing!!

Reviews.Title: “dont listen to bad reviews!! it's great!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: i read the reviews here and was nervous about the hotel, since we'd already booked it. when we arrived, what a nice surprise! the room was lovely... sparkling clean and comfortable. we arrived at 10am and were let into our room to nap despite check in not being til 3. the continental breakfast is nice... croissants, cereal, coffee etc. the staff was helpful as could be. the hotel is convenient to the tube and is really lovely all-around. you will NOT regret staying here!

Reviews.Title: “Good location but crappy breakfast.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed on the second floor of this hotel. We had a good room. The bathroom was very clean. Beds were a little on the soft side in my opinion. The breakfast is really crap. Only some chemical jam substance and butter to put on your bread. Staff kindness was average. The location however was very good. I have read that there are rooms that are very bad but ours was clean and comfy!

Reviews.Title: “Nice place”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: It's not bad. Good beds, clean rooms, nice lobby, nice staff, good included continental breakfast. I can only complain about the elevators. Only 2 of 3 worked and were very busy in peak hours. If someday I go back to London, I will try to reserve in this hotel

Reviews.Title: “Not a good first impression”
Reviews.Author: NSinUAE
Reviews.Content: When we arrived at around the 2:00 p.m check-in time we were told to come back in about two hours. We did so and our check-in went well. The room was adequate, it had two single beds and a small fridge. The biggest complaint was the paper-thin walls. We reported noise next door one night and management was quick to respond and all went quiet. We also had one incident of a man talking rather loudly to a woman in the room next to ours. With most hotels that we have stayed in, the bedding is changed daily. Not here, my wife had to persuade the housekeeping staff to change the sheets once during out three night stay. On the positive side, the hotel was very close to Hyde Park, two tube stations and the bus lines. There was a continental breakfast included with our room. It was very basic, cereal, toast and coffee but adequate.

Reviews.Title: “Good location”
Reviews.Author: SantiagoABQ
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel for a week in 9/04 and from reading other reviews I knew to request one of the newly refurbished rooms. We were on the third floor and you could tell everything was new in the room and it was very comfortable. This is definitely not a "4 Star" hotel but for basic accommodations it is fine with a good location. We were close to 2 tube stops and since the hotel is located on a side street it was basically quiet at night. Breakfast was a waste, but other than that, this is a good, centrally located hotel in London.

Reviews.Title: “Dreadful - Not a 3 star hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Unclean lobby, non-working lift, unhelpful staff, dirty room with cigarette burns in the wall, and should be listed as a 1 star hotel. If there are better rooms on the first three floors, those are the only ones that should be given out. Unfortunately, I did not read all of the reviews before our trip. While I do not expect a 3 star hotel to have mints on the pillow and bellmen to jump at my every whim, I do expect it to be CLEAN! I want a clean room with a clean bathroom without cigarette burns in the wall next to the bed. Unfortunately, they felt the hour that we were checked in warranted charging us for the night. That hour, we left our luggage in the room to find a different hotel. We did find a different hotel, it is listed as a 3 star hotel and in my book it is a 3 star hotel - clean.

Reviews.Title: “Great location”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Stayed there 2 nights- on the way into Europe & one night on our way out. When we arrived the 1st time we were put into an "ok" room- but hey it was a bed that was much needed- very quiet, clean- decent bathroom, clean & a great powerful shower. Room was on the "well used" side- but wasnt horrible- the hallway smelled like a Greatfull Dead concert- the bong was doing double time down the hall.... The location is great- right across the street from Kensington Gardens & 2 blocks from a great Indian restaurant- (Majaraja) as well as a tube stop. So its a very good location- Concierge was very helpfull. On the way back- ended up being put in a room that was not made up- so they upgraded us to a larger room that was recently renovated (someone paid attention in hotel class) room 304- sitting room & seperate bedroom- room to spread out. Try to get a room on the 1st, 2nd or 3 floor- as they have been re-done. Didnt eat there as were told it wasnt a good breakfast- but there is lots to get on the go right around the corner. Not a bad place- great value.

Reviews.Title: “Location very handy,Accomodation about average.”
Reviews.Author: offare
Reviews.Content: My wife,young son and I stayed here from 15-19th of July and found it to be pretty o.k.The hotel however would probably be rated a two star in Ireland and reminded me of where some hotels in the west of Ireland were at about ten years ago. That said however we found the bedroom/ensuite to be comfortable although small.The continental breakfast was o.k. and there was also a full English breakfast for four pounds.Tea/coffee making facilities in the bedroom were provided and also a fridge.There was a safe also but the key for this could not be located when we checked in. There is a bar on the premises but the selection of drinks is pretty limited.The T.V. in the bar also seems to repeat the same programs over and over,mainly foreign MTV/Sport. The best feature of this hotel is easily location.Queensway is just around the corner and Hyde Park just a stroll across the street.If you are staying on a Sunday there is a wonderful selection of original art on display on the Bayswater Road. Overall I would stay here again,its fair value for the price.

HotelInfo.Name: Central Park Hotel
HotelInfo.Address: 49-67 Queensborough Terrace, London W2 3SS, England
